case_vignette: A 70-year-old man presents with 1 year of a non-healing growth on the right cheek. He says he first noticed it when he accidentally bumped into it and it bled easily. He denies any preceding trauma to the lesion.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a growth on my right cheek that hasn't healed for a year, and it bleeds easily if I bump into it.

I first noticed it a year ago, but I haven't observed any change in its size, shape, or color over time.

I haven't mentioned anything about sun exposure or the use of tanning beds.
Do you have a family history of skin cancer?
I haven't mentioned anything about my family history or whether there's a history of skin cancer in my family.
Is the surface of the growth smooth, shiny, waxy, or does it have a scaly texture?
I haven't described the specific texture or surface appearance of the growth on my cheek.

I haven't mentioned whether the growth is tender or painful when touched.
Have you experienced any weight loss, fevers, or night sweats recently?
I haven't mentioned experiencing weight loss, fevers, or night sweats recently.
Do you have any other skin lesions or unusual spots elsewhere on your body?
I haven't mentioned any other skin lesions or unusual spots elsewhere on my body.
Has the growth been previously evaluated or treated by a healthcare professional?
I haven't mentioned whether the growth has been previously evaluated or treated by a healthcare professional.
**Final Diagnosis:** Basal cell carcinoma.
